DOC.HEAD: Ruling Party, ex-Opposition Formally Merge to Map New Policy
DOC.TEXT: The ruling party and main opposition merged Tuesday with their first national congress, charged with framing a new constitution. Since independence a decade ago, President Robert Mugabe's dominant Zimbabwe African National Union (Patriotic Front) has been avowedly Marxist-Leninist. Former Zimbabwe African People's Union opposition leader Joshua Nkomo was more centrist. About 4,200 delegates from the two parties gathered for the four-day congress that will decide which ideological path to tread in the light of changes in Eastern Europe, long Mugabe's role model. Conferees also will be asked to rule whether the new alliance should continue to pursue Mugabe's dream of creating a one-party state in one of Africa's few Western-style democracies. The congress effectively formalizes a decision by Zimbabwe's two main political figures two years ago to unite their parties, ending decades of interparty feuding. The alliance also seeks to bury 200 years of tribal hostilities between the majority Shona tribe, which largely backs Mugabe, and the Ndebele people who traditionally support Nkomo. The birth of the reconstituted ZANU arms Mugabe with the support of all but two lawmakers in the 100-seat National Assembly and the 40-member rubber-stamp senate. The ruling party can pass laws and rewrite sections of the British-drafted constitution, a document signed by all parties at London's Lancaster House 10 years ago Thursday. Those constitutional talks ended nine decades of white minority rule, halted a seven-year war waged by guerrillas loyal to Nkomo and Mugabe and transformed the British colony of Rhodesia into black-governed Zimbabwe at independence April 18, 1980. The constitution guaranteed Zimbabwe would be a multiparty democracy for the first 10 years of independence. After the 10th anniversary, Mugabe can, constitutionally, ban opposition and establish a single-party state with two-thirds of the votes in Parliament. But in recent months, as pro-democratic movements have swept Eastern Europe, Mugabe has come under mounting pressure to renounce what he calls his Marxist-Leninist policies and to abandon the aim of killing the multiparty system. Opening the congress, Mugabe indicated his stand was flexible. ``While we must be clear as to the ideological direction we take ... namely Marxist-Leninist socialist principles, we must also take full cognisance of the environment and the concrete realities in which we seek to achieve social transformation,'' he said. The congress, which ends Friday, is being attended also by Presidents Quett Masire of Botswana and Kenneth Kaunda of Zambia as well as observers from 20 countries including Cuba, North Korea and Nicaragua.
